name: Kieka Mynhardt
content:
Christina Magdalena (Kieka) Mynhardt (née Steyn, born 1953)[1] is a South African mathematician known for her work on dominating sets in graph theory, including domination versions of the eight queens puzzle.[2] She is a professor of mathematics and statistics at the University of Victoria in Canada.
 Mynhardt was born in Cape Town,[1][3] and was a student at the Hoërskool Lichtenburg.[1] She completed her Ph.D. at Rand Afrikaans University (now incorporated into the University of Johannesburg) in 1979, supervised by Izak Broere.[4] Her dissertation, The 





G




{\displaystyle {\mathcal {G}}}

-constructability of graphs, gave a conjectured construction for the planar graphs by repeatedly adding vertices with prescribed neighborhoods.[5]
She became a faculty member at the University of Pretoria and then the University of South Africa before moving to the University of Victoria.[3]
 In 1995, Mynhardt was selected as one of the founding members of the Academy of Science of South Africa.[6]
She was a 2005 recipient of the Dignitas Award of the University of Johannesburg Alumni.[7]
tags: Members of the Academy of Science of South Africa
raw:
South African and Canadian mathematician
Christina Magdalena (Kieka) Mynhardt (née Steyn, born 1953)[1] is a South African mathematician known for her work on dominating sets in graph theory, including domination versions of the eight queens puzzle.[2] She is a professor of mathematics and statistics at the University of Victoria in Canada.

Contents

1 Education and career
2 Recognition
3 References
4 External links


Education and career[edit]
Mynhardt was born in Cape Town,[1][3] and was a student at the Hoërskool Lichtenburg.[1] She completed her Ph.D. at Rand Afrikaans University (now incorporated into the University of Johannesburg) in 1979, supervised by Izak Broere.[4] Her dissertation, The 





G




{\displaystyle {\mathcal {G}}}

-constructability of graphs, gave a conjectured construction for the planar graphs by repeatedly adding vertices with prescribed neighborhoods.[5]
She became a faculty member at the University of Pretoria and then the University of South Africa before moving to the University of Victoria.[3]

Recognition[edit]
In 1995, Mynhardt was selected as one of the founding members of the Academy of Science of South Africa.[6]
She was a 2005 recipient of the Dignitas Award of the University of Johannesburg Alumni.[7]
